comments.commentBody: That's an assumption that isn't born out by the fact that the US has vetoed UN Resolutions to resolve the relationship between the state of Israel and the Palestinian people.  The US has done this for decades.

From an article on TPM, entitled "Obamacare Enrollment Is Far From Over:"

"The ACA’s state Marketplaces, in contrast, provide a non-discriminatory home for those losing their insurance coverage. In many cases, the loss of insurance coverage is what is known as a “qualifying event” that allows individuals to purchase insurance on their state Marketplace even after the open enrollment deadline. And for those seeing a sharp drop in income due to job loss, the tax credits available through the ACA exchanges can provide a much more affordable option than COBRA; in about half of the states, Medicaid will also be available for those suffering the largest income losses."

The rest of the piece is an excellent read.

http://talkingpointsmemo.com/cafe/obamacare-enrollment-is-far-from-over

I relate to the ongoing dilemmas expressed by Christin Taylor.  I speak as a former evangelical who has moved away from that branch of Christianity.  The transition was not without pain, and I can largely thank the church I attend, with its openness to honest and non-judgmental inquiries, for enabling me to find a theological niche--one that I am comfortable sharing with my university friends.  My church provides many opportunities to live out my Christian faith to address major social issues such as economic justice, an issue that fills the pages of the Old Testament prophets and the gospels. Books by Marcus Borg, especially "The Heart of Christianity", have been incredibly helpful to me in my spiritual journey.

How strange--just watched that movie last night.

Tonight it was "The Maltese Falcon".
Translation: girls were mean to me, so I can be mean to them.

Thank you for this! As a fashion designer in New York I am about as far from the women in Silicone Valley as the tech nerds are from male models. However I suspected that the glass ceiling in Silicone Valley was about 2" high when both The Social Network and Jobs portrayed all women characters as total cliches. The Social Network had no female roles of note, and Jobs' girlfriend, as the clingy type and subsequently his wife as mother and cook, were embarrassing one-dimensional stereotypes. And a recent event at the PAMM Museum in Miami Jaron Lanier, Clive Thompson and Michael Chabon  were billed as the "Prophets of the Digital Age." I noted no women on this panel, and wondered whether Thompson and Chabon really compared next to the true prophet Lanier and if maybe Sheryl Sandberg would have been a wiser choice as one prophette. And then there is Susan McTavish Best, the Grand Dame of Silicon Valley and former girlfriend of Craig List's Jim Buckmaster. MacTavish Best has made a career out of being the lifestyle guru (think Martha Stewart) for the tech set, doling out advice on how to spend their newfound wealth on home furnishings, cool clothes, be social, throw parties and write thank-you notes ... thus filling the female energy vacuum in the lives of these tech advanced men.

People have forgotten that, once upon a time, climate scientists made confident predictions and forecasts.

When, in 2008, I pointed this out, an environmental writer for a major metropolitan newspaper, who shall remain nameless, except that his initials are A.R. and he runs a blog named Dot Earth, rebuked me, saying, "[James]Hansen made if-then projections. Not forecasts. Never were, never will be."

When I quoted Hansen's 1988 JGL paper, which had "forecasts" in the title and used the word "predictions" three times in the abstract and about six times in the text, said nameless but well-beloved reporter replied, "I'll ask him about that."

Six years later, I have never received an answer to that question.

Early on, even the IPCC had to admit that weather and climate are fundamentally unpredictable on a theoretical level.

Thereafter the IPCC outputs were labeled as "projections" and latterly "scenarios". NOT, heaven forefend, predictions or forecasts.

Then policy-makers promptly ignored the relabelling and treated the projections and scenarios as predictions when they crafted their policies.

This semantic fan-dance would be much less disturbing if the "projections" had any resemblance to reality. Their record over the last 26 years has been distinctly inferior.

Compare a plot of James Hansen's 1988 predictions (for that is what they were) for temperature rise under the "business as usual" scenario versus the RSS data for that same period.

Epic fail.
Absolutely. White men have invented too much stuff. It makes other people feel bad, and that's unforgivable.
I remember learning dilemna too.

I think the problem begins in high schools. I went to a small public school in the suburbs of New York. My graduating class was evenly split between men and women. My AP chemistry course, however, had no more than five women out of about 20 students. AP physics had even fewer-- no women at all. Computer science wasn't offered.

Not only is it necessary for advisers to encourage young women to aim for engineering, it's also important to hire female science teachers who can act as role models for future engineers. I can't think of any women from my graduating high school class who went into engineering.

In my college class, male engineers outnumber female engineers 3 to 1.
I loved the puns. I inflict them on my family. A fun PB puzzle in my opinion.

Eich's big problem was his intransigence - his refusal to make any comment - pro or con. And considering how facile corporate and political leaders are at spinning apologies until there's really no culpability on their part, he could easily have done that. No, it's his intransigence that would have been unacceptable in a leader.

You make no sense.

Wanting sex and being sexist are not the same thing.

I am a female programmer working for a start-up in science, another male-dominated field. Reading articles like this makes me feel stronger. It makes me realize that I'm not alone. It makes me realize that yes, other women experience this too, they are also marginalized and grasping at options, and have no idea what to do. Do I speak up? Do I take it and smile and joke and be one of the guys? Do I hide?

Articles like this make me realize I didn't do something to deserve this. It is not OK to receive death threats (yes, me too) because I work hard and want my company to succeed. Reading this makes me want to push harder and encourage other women to do the same. Should Ms. Shevinsky have continued to work with that guy? There is no clear path, we just don't know. None of us knows which option to take. Stand up for yourself. Keep coding. Be strong.

"The past couple of millennia demonstrate this problem to an alarming degree. Men are simply too efficient at creating industries, and then excelling in them. Even worse, the neanderthals quickly decide that they work better under, and even personally enjoy, an atmosphere that is conducive to men. This has to stop. "

Men are too efficient? Atmosphere conducive to men has to stop?

Nice parody, or you are arguing against human progress.

What HHS has failed to acknowledge is that about 30 percent of every premium dollar goes to insurance middlemen who provide ‘zero’ health care and administrative waste on the provider end due to a multi-payer system. It has also left out that Americans pay, by far, the highest drug prices in the world. It comes as no surprise that HHS does not want to go up against two of our most powerful lobbying forces: the insurance and pharmaceutical industries.
In 1960 Medicare and Medicaid did not exist and a huge percentage of people had no health care at all.

The exact figure for the medical loss ratio, the official doublespeak term for administrative cost/profit, is 20%. The ACA caps the medical loss ratio at 20% of your premium dollar, which means for every dollar you pay in insurance premiums, 20 cents goes to pay data entry workers (the exact same workers who also code for Medicare at 3 cents on the dollar), dividends and CEO salaries, which average in the millions.

Why do Americans pay twice as much for our healthcare? Because we allow insurance companies, pharmaceuticals, medical device manufacturers and for profit providers to charge whatever they damn well please, while our political pretend that life saving drugs and medical treatments are something you can 'shop' for.

'The nation’s spending on medical care has been on an unrelenting upward path for a number of decades. In 1960, aggregate health expenditures in the U.S. totaled $27 billion; in 2003, the figure stood at nearly $1.7 trillion — a 63-fold rise. In contrast, the U.S. population grew by only 51 percent. Health expenditures per capita (or per person) rose from $143 in 1960 to $5,670 in 2003 — a 40-fold rise. General inflation pushed up prices of goods and services in the economy by 5-fold. In contrast, the recorded rise in prices for medical care was 12-fold, driven mostly by increases in hospital charges and doctors’ fees. The overall economic dimensions of the growth have been equally impressive, with the share of the economy devoted to health care tripling over the period, rising from approximately 5 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1960 to over 15 percent in 2003.'

~ http://aspe.hhs.gov/health/MedicalExpenditures/
I guess everything with these software engineers would be okay if they confined their harassment to interns and pages.
Miguel, absolutely nobody has suggested that but you.
It's fun to read this while the Times runs an article about David Letterman's replacement being a comic, or a general performer, or a woman.

We don't need to give equal time to misogyny.  The boy-puerile atmosphere is everywhere--in universities, in the military, on Wall Street, in politics, journalism, medicine, everywhere.  And it is this attitude that is killing and will kill our planet, because it lacks conscience and a heart.  And it embraces resentment and whining as an MO. Personally, I've seen enough.  Killing all of life so that you can be superior and win just doesn't cut it. Without backing off this stuff, there will be no way to collaborate on saving anything at all.  Yes, I'm cynical, but I got that way from first hand experience, so much of it that I've pretty much given up.  The engineering department of the university where I work is just the same. Pumping them out by the hundreds.
There are plenty of 26-year-old virgins who know how to act like human beings.  There's nothing magical about sex that makes you suddenly have manners.
C'mon. Give a bunch of 26 year-old virgins big honkin' loads of money, and this is what you get.
"Men simply need to stop innovating". You cannot seriously believe that statement. How does it help anyone, male or female, for intelligent people not to use their talents to create new things?
The New York Times appears to have been pranked by the amusing Ms. Shevinsky into giving a huge dose of national publicity to her semi-pornographic sexting app in the name of Fighting Sexism.

That an app where men share pictures of themselves staring goggle eyed at anonymous womens' chests has had its developers named and shamed is excellent news...  I'm glad that Dickinson and Shevinsky were reconciled through Dickinson's apology so they were able to get back to the important work of allowing people to safely sext around behind their partners' backs.

Our grandchildren will despise software engineers they way we despise lawyers and journalists.

If we have any grandchildren.

"A culprit, many people in the field say, is a sexist, alpha-male culture that can make women and other people who don’t fit the mold feel unwelcome, demeaned or even endangered."

The entire tech culture is dehumanizing by definition. Techies are corporate storm troopers.

Yes, maybe she was insecure, but where do you think that came from? Years of being treated inferior due to her gender. Quit blaming the victim & acting like you can't tell when someone's laughing at you.

It is not an industry onto itself unlike any industry in history.  I started in 78 with a large now defunct computer company(fortune 100) where you worked 8-5 and all the managers were family men mostly trained in the military (mostly communication Korea/Vietnam types).  Fast forward to 2000(and later) and 24/7/365 processing and so much coding is done in Asia(overnight) and implementation done overnight/weekends that the way to get ahead is to have no family life, no social outside interests(most sports  are karate, scuba, gun range types) and no community roots.  Most men reject this life, almost all women do. I work as a "mole" with network lab rats who talk about "canned goods and ammunition" and as one who must leave by 6 knows that I am in the checkout lane.  Also, whether you are spirtual or not there is a trend towards agnoticism or atheism and it hurts not to be able to mention my girls decent Catholic school team sports record at work knowing it would be sneered at an belittled.  Not fun and nothing like I expected when i started.

Undoubtedly this is also the reason there are so few women who are coal miners.

Or men who are grade school teachers.

As to tech, as far as I know, Ned Ludd was not sexist.
